awd_titl_txt: GOALI: System Transition toward Sustainability under Uncertainty: Theoretic Framework and Engineering Method Development
awd_abstract_narration:
1604756 
Huang, Yinlun

The objective of this project is to develop a theoretic framework for modeling technology-driven transition toward sustainability for industrial systems and derive optimal development strategies under uncertainties. Sustainable development is a process that targets a future state of sustainability for industries, the environment, and societies. Sustainable development is the pathway to sustainability, which is chiefly featured by a system's transition from one state to another toward sustainability goals. This project is designed provide scientific answers to the following questions: Is a preset sustainability goal achievable under known constraints? If yes, how to manage the state transition process in an optimal way? If no, then how to set an achievable sustainability goal, or how to identify the main obstacle(s) so that the preset goal becomes achievable? In this GOALI project, Wayne State University and BASF researchers will jointly study key fundamental aspects of sustainable development of industrial systems, namely triple-bottom-line-balanced development (economic, environmental, social) and goal achievability under uncertainty. The theoretic framework and engineering methodology to be developed should be valuable for studying a wide spectrum of sustainability problems in any industry and beyond.
 
The specific objectives are to (i) develop a theoretic framework for technology-driven system transition toward sustainability, (ii) generate a unique engineering method for designing sustainable and controllable systems, (iii) derive optimal development strategies that allow decision makers' active participation, and (iv) construct a software tool embedding the design method, which will be used to study sophisticated industrial sustainability problems through collaboration with BASF. The project will use a vector analysis technique to analyze the sustainability state transition problem, and to apply the supervisory-regulatory control technique to formulate and manage the sustainability state transition process. The project will generate educational materials for enhancing an introductory course on sustainable engineering open to all engineering students at WAyne State University. The methodology and the tool will be disseminated through the Sustainable Manufacturing Advances in Research and Technology (SMART) Coordination Network that the PI chairs, and the AIChE Sustainable Engineering Forum, as well as publication. Short courses and seminars will be arranged with industry. The developed case studies and computer tool will be structured for use by the students in the NSF REU site program - Summer Academy in Sustainable Engineering at Wayne State University.

por.por_cntn:
Depletion of nonrenewable resources, global warming, air, water, and soil pollution, excessive population growth, etc., have challenged societies globally. These demand industries to seriously review engineering practice and find ways to ensure development sustainability. Over the past decade, sustainable engineering has emerged as a vibrant field of research and innovation. Numerous sustainability assessment and enhancement methods and technologies have been developed and used to improve material and energy efficiency, environmental cleanness, plant safety, human health, product life-cycle performance, and social responsibility. However, sustainable development plans and strategies are derived mostly based on experience; they could be effective in tackling relatively simple sustainability problems, not involving complex multi-stage or mid-to-long-term strategic development. Fundamentally, sustainable development is a system science problem that can be characterized by a series of system transitions toward more sustainable states under uncertainty. Theoretical study in this area is essential to the development of science-driven engineering methods for investigating complex sustainable development problems.

The major goal of the project is the development of a theoretic framework for modeling technology-driven transition toward sustainability for industrial systems and a systematic methodology for deriving optimal development strategies under uncertainty. Through implementing this project, we are able to provide scientific answers to the following questions: Is a preset sustainability goal achievable under various constraints? If yes, how to manage the state transition process in an optimal way? If no, then how to set an achievable sustainability goal, or how to identify the main obstacle(s) so that the preset goal becomes achievable? We have completed our study on key fundamental aspects of sustainable development of industrial systems, namely triple-bottom-line-balanced development and goal achievability under uncertainty, and developed a powerful methodology for analyzing the sustainability performance of an industrial system of any type, and for generating optimal solutions to enhance the system’s sustainability performance in a possibly multi-stage process in different development scenarios, such as those for maximum sustainability performance improvement, minimum cost, minimum time requirement, or maximum efficiency of improvement, under various constraints, such as those related to budget, regulation, market, technical and non-technical aspects.  The developed theoretic framework and engineering methodology have been successfully used to study a number of industrial problems, through collaborating with industrial partners.  It is shown that the theoretical framework and the methodology are general and they should be applicable to a wide spectrum of sustainability problems in a variety of industries for deriving short-to-long term development strategies under uncertainty.

This project has also resulted in the development of pedagogical approaches for incorporating sustainability-centered research results into undergraduate and graduate education.  The improved team-based learning and experiential learning approaches have benefited the undergraduate students for addressing sustainability issues in a senior capstone design course, the upper division/first year graduate students for learning sustainability concepts and applying basic sustainability assessment and decision making methods in an introductory course on sustainable engineering, and the graduate students for mathematically describing sustainability problems with solution in an advanced engineering mathematics  course.  The gained educational experience has been and will be continuously shared with engineering education communities.
